body:
Saint Aye

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Aye
Died ~711
Belgium
Venerated in Roman Catholic Church
Feast April 18
Patronage lawsuits

Aye (died c. 711) is a Belgian Catholic saint. [1] She has been referred to also as Aia , [2] Agia , [3] and St. Austregildis . [4] Aye is sometimes confused with another St. Agia, the mother of the French Saint Loup of Sens . [4]

Aye is revered by the Beguines of Belgium . Her Feast Day is April 18. [1] [4] [2] .

Little is known about Aye's early life or date of birth, but available sources state that she was the daughter of Brunulph, count d’Arennes and a relative of Saint Waldetrudis . [1] She was married to Saint Hidulf of Hainault until both decided to enter religious life, after which point they parted ways. [3]

Aye joined the Abbey of Mons in Belgium, where she became a nun , and gave her property away to the nuns of Saint Waldetrudis. [2] The date of her death is not concretely known as sources place her death around the year 707 as well as 714. [4]

Aye is known as the patron saint of lawsuits . She is believed to have gained the title due to a lawsuit that decided "her heirs against the Canonesses of Mons". [1] A variant legend states that she righted an injustice by speaking from beyond the grave. [5]

References [ edit ]

  1. ^ a b c d Holweck, Frederick (1924). A Biographical Dictionary of the Saints . Detroit: Gale Research Co: Bloomsbury Academic. p. 126.
  2. ^ a b c Attwater, Donald (1958). A Dictionary of Saints . New York: .J. Kennedy & Sons. pp. 7 .
  3. ^ a b Englebert, Omer (1951). The Lives of the Saints . New York: David McKay Company INC. pp. 151 .
  4. ^ a b c d Andre-Driussi, Michael (2008). Lexicon Urthus, Second Edition . Sirius Fiction. p. 8.
  5. ^ "Saint Agia of Hainault" . CatholicSaints.Info . 2012-04-18 . Retrieved 2019-05-19 .

Little is known about Aye's early life or date of birth, but available sources state that she was the daughter of Brunulph, count d’Arennes and a relative of Saint Waldetrudis .
